M.G.L. c. 186, \u00a714.proposition: Under M.G.L. c. 186, §14, a landlord who “directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant” is liable for actual and statutory damages.

M.G.L. c. 218, \u00a719.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this Court pursuant to M.G.L. c. 218, §19 and M.G.L. c. 231, §1, as the amount in controversy does not exceed the jurisdictional limits of the District Court and the claims arise under Massachusetts law.

M.G.L. c. 231, \u00a71.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this Court pursuant to M.G.L. c. 218, §19 and M.G.L. c. 231, §1, as the amount in controversy does not exceed the jurisdictional limits of the District Court and the claims arise under Massachusetts law.

M.G.L. c. 223, \u00a78.proposition: Venue is proper in the Cambridge District Court pursuant to M.G.L. c. 223, §8, because the property that is the subject of this action is located within this Court’s territorial jurisdiction.

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: The statute provides that such interference, if substantial and without justification, constitutes a breach irrespective of the landlord’s intent. See Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977).
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The opinion does hold that a landlord’s intent to deprive the tenant is not required for a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment/constructive eviction, but it does not state that this is because of any statute; it treats the rule as a matter of common-law development. The proposition inaccurately attributes a statutory basis (“The statute provides…”) to what Blackett describes as a judicial rule focused on the landlord’s conduct rather than intent, so the case does not support the proposition as phrased.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “Our opinions concerning a constructive eviction by an alleged breach of an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment sometimes have stated that the landlord must perform some act with the intent of depriving the tenant of the enjoyment and occupation of the whole or part of the leased premises… Although some of our opinions have spoken of particular action or inaction by a landlord as showing a presumed intention to evict, the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Courts have found comparable disturbances to violate the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See, e.g.:
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The case squarely addresses the scope of the covenant/statutory right of quiet enjoyment and holds that repeated flooding and unsanitary water intrusion into an apartment constitutes interference with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, building on common-law quiet enjoyment principles. The court affirms that serious interference such as repeated floods that impair the character and value of the premises violates quiet enjoyment, which fits the proposition that comparable disturbances have been found to breach that covenant.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: The phrase “quiet enjoyment” is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that “impair the character and value of the leased premises.” Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33, 36 (1929) (quoting from Brande v. Grace, 154 Mass. 210, 212 [1891]). See Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977). Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy. Id. ... Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: Courts have found comparable disturbances to violate the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See, e.g.:
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The proposition is that comparable disturbances have been held to violate the covenant of quiet enjoyment. This case squarely holds that a landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season “constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment” and imposes liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14. It therefore directly supports the general proposition that such serious interferences with basic services violate the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season … seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’ … and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See generally Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715-716 (1977), and cases cited.”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: Courts have found comparable disturbances to violate the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See, e.g.:
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The proposition suggests this case is an example where comparable disturbances were found to violate the covenant of quiet enjoyment. In fact, the court in Al‑Ziab does not identify any disturbance and does not find a violation of the covenant; instead, it holds that violation of the lead paint statute alone does not establish a breach of quiet enjoyment and vacates the attorney’s fee award under that statute. The opinion discusses prior cases where quiet enjoyment was breached, but Al‑Ziab itself is not authority that such disturbances constitute a violation.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.

Wendt v. Handler, 85 Mass. App. Ct. 162.raw_text: Wendt v. Handler, 85 Mass. App. Ct. 162 (2014)
Wendt v. Handler, 85 Mass. App. Ct. 162.proposition: Courts have found comparable disturbances to violate the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See, e.g.:
Wendt v. Handler, 85 Mass. App. Ct. 162.support_reasoning: The quoted opinion is about negligence, the Massachusetts recreational use statute, and Chapter 93A consumer protection claims arising from a fall at Old North Church. It does not involve landlord‑tenant law, leasehold interests, or the covenant of quiet enjoyment, nor does it discuss any type of disturbance analogous to quiet enjoyment violations. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority that comparable disturbances violate the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Wendt v. Handler, 85 Mass. App. Ct. 162.relevant_excerpt: The excerpted text contains no discussion of quiet enjoyment, leaseholds, or tenant rights; it is limited to issues under G. L. c. 21, § 17C (recreational use statute) and G. L. c. 93A (consumer protection), and thus provides no support for a proposition about the covenant of quiet enjoyment.

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Courts have found comparable disturbances to violate the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See, e.g.:
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The proposition is that courts have found comparable disturbances to violate the covenant of quiet enjoyment. This opinion squarely addresses that issue and holds that if drug-related activity in common areas so interferes with tenants’ ability to use sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreation areas, it can constitute a serious interference with quiet enjoyment and a breach of the covenant. The court reverses summary judgment on the quiet enjoyment claim precisely because such disturbances may amount to a violation, making the case good authority for the proposition.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “[I]f the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development, including sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreation areas within it, then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises… If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.raw_text: Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 744 (2005)
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.proposition: Courts have found comparable disturbances to violate the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See, e.g.:
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.support_reasoning: The proposition asserts that courts have found comparable disturbances to violate the covenant of quiet enjoyment. In this case, the court holds the opposite: it finds no breach of the covenant and expressly states it sees no evidence of interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment. Thus, this opinion would not be proper authority for the claim that similar conditions amount to a quiet enjoyment violation; it is contrary authority.
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.relevant_excerpt: “Here, York acted immediately upon being notified by Casey of the defective conditions. While these conditions were documented by the board of health pursuant to an inspection, a reinspection less than two weeks later indicated that substantially all the conditions had been satisfactorily addressed. The trial judge did not err in denying the requested ruling of law that a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment had occurred. We see no evidence in the record before us of interference with Casey’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.”

Emigrant Mtge. Co. v. D\u2019Agostino, 8.raw_text: Emigrant Mtge. Co. v. D’Agostino, 89 Mass. App. Ct. 1114 (2016)
Emigrant Mtge. Co. v. D\u2019Agostino, 8.proposition: Courts have found comparable disturbances to violate the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See, e.g.:

Auburn Woods Homeowners Ass\u2019n v. Fa.raw_text: Auburn Woods Homeowners Ass’n v. Fair Housing Council of Oregon, 490 U.S. 99 (1989, analogy to nuisance principle as applied in MA law)
Auburn Woods Homeowners Ass\u2019n v. Fa.proposition: Defendant’s knowledge of the disturbance, combined with his failure to prevent or minimize its impact, establishes a “direct or indirect interference” under the meaning of the statute. See Auburn Woods Homeowners Ass’n v. Fair Housing Council of Oregon, 490 U.S. 99 (1989, analogy to nuisance principle as applied in MA law); Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979).
Auburn Woods Homeowners Ass\u2019n v. Fa.support_reasoning: The opinion is California v. ARC America Corp., an antitrust preemption case about indirect purchaser standing under state antitrust statutes. It does not discuss nuisance principles, ‘disturbance,’ a defendant’s knowledge, or ‘direct or indirect interference’ in the sense used in property or housing statutes, nor does it concern Massachusetts law. The case is focused on whether state indirect-purchaser remedies are preempted by federal antitrust law and thus does not provide authority for the interference/knowledge proposition asserted.
Auburn Woods Homeowners Ass\u2019n v. Fa.relevant_excerpt: “The issue before us is whether this rule limiting recoveries under the Sherman Act also prevents indirect purchasers from recovering damages flowing from violations of state law, despite express state statutory provisions giving such purchasers a damages cause of action.… When viewed properly, Illinois Brick was a decision construing the federal antitrust laws, not a decision defining the interrelationship between the federal and state antitrust laws.”

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: Defendant’s knowledge of the disturbance, combined with his failure to prevent or minimize its impact, establishes a “direct or indirect interference” under the meaning of the statute. See Auburn Woods Homeowners Ass’n v. Fair Housing Council of Oregon, 490 U.S. 99 (1989, analogy to nuisance principle as applied in MA law); Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979).
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The case concerns breach of the implied warranty of habitability and when a tenant’s rent obligation abates once the landlord has notice of code-based defects. It does not analyze “direct or indirect interference” language or a statutory interference standard, nor does it hinge liability on the landlord’s failure to prevent or minimize a disturbance. Instead, the court imposes essentially strict contractual/warranty liability upon notice, expressly separating this from fault-based or deterrence concepts. Therefore it does not support the stated interference proposition.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “We hold that the tenant’s obligation abates as soon as the landlord has notice that premises fail to comply with the requirements of the warranty of habitability. The landlord’s lack of fault and reasonable efforts to repair do not prolong the duty to pay full rent.… [T]he warranty of habitability is not designed to penalize the landlord for misbehavior. In the rent abatement context, the doctrine imposes a duty quite apart from notions of moral sanction or deterrence.”
